Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Raman Spectroscopic Methods for the Identification of Trace Evidence
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Researchers from the City College of New York, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art will develop methods for the evaluation of trace evidence and the examination of questioned documents by surface-enhanced Raman scattering. The focus is on pursuing non-destructive methods of analysis and techniques involving combination of Raman spectroscopy with other separation methods for the analysis of complex samples. This multidisciplinary collaboration seeks to achieve significant advances in the application of surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) analysis to the evaluation of trace evidence and the examination of questioned documents. The project will continue to develop the core of a searchable spectral library of substances of forensic interest such as organic dyes and pigments, pharmaceuticals, and drugs of abuse. The involvement of undergraduate, Masters level, and PhD students in the research will also result in a substantial contribution to the training of the future generation of forensic scientists.

In this research, the investigators plan to focus on approaches for SERS analysis by developing standardized reproducible protocols for analysis of ink (including gel pen inks and black inks) and fiber samples, controlled substances, as well as colorants used in fabrics and paints. They will also develop procedures to deal with matrix interferences in SERS spectra, and continue to work on methods for completely non-destructive SERS analysis of documents and textiles, expanding the range of solvent systems and gel formulations to include easily available gelling materials such as agar and methylcellulose. The researchers will develop extraction procedures for gel pen and black inks suitable for SERS analysis and hyphenated techniques such as high performance thin-layer chromatography (HPTLC)-SERS for the separation and identification of mixtures.

Project Outcomes Report-2019

 

NSF Award # 1042750

Advanced Raman Spectroscopic Methods for the Identification of Trace Evidence
John Lombardi lombardi@sci.ccny.cuny.edu (Principal Investigator)
Marco Leona (Co-Principal Investigator)
Thomas Kubic (Co-Principal Investigator)

Report

            In this project supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Researchers from the City College of New York, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art have developed methods for the evaluation of trace evidence and the examination of questioned documents by surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). The focus has been on non-destructive methods of analysis and techniques involving combination of Raman spectroscopy with other separation methods for the analysis of complex samples. This multidisciplinary collaboration has achieved significant advances in the application of SERS analysis to the evaluation of trace evidence and the examination of questioned documents. The project has developed the core of a searchable spectral library of substances of forensic interest such as organic dyes and pigments, pharmaceuticals, and drugs of abuse. The involvement of undergraduate, Masters level, and PhD students in the research has also resulted in a substantial contribution to the training of the future generation of forensic scientists.

The following describes some of our accomplishments:

Dye Mixtures

This research presents a successful study in surface-enhanced Raman quantitation of dyes present in mixtures of alizarin and purpurin by using standard calibration curves and Langmuir isotherm calibration models. Investigations of the nature of competitive adsorption onto silver nanoparticles by centrifugation indicates that both dyes in the mixture interact with the nanoparticles simultaneously, but only the stronger adsorbing one is seen as dominating the spectral characteristics. Calibration was done by carefully selecting non-overlapping peaks characteristic of each dye in the mixture. Comparisons of peak height and peak area calibrations reveal that peak heights, when carefully selected by the maximum value and accounting for peak shifts, prove the better model for quantitation. It is also shown that the used nanoparticle synthesis method produces stable nanoparticles that can be used for at least one year with very little variation within and between uses.

 

SERS of Synthetic Cannabinoids

The application of surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) has been shown to be a fast and sensitive analytical method in the trace detection of the two most commonly known synthetic cannabinoids AMB-FUBINACA and alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone (a-PVP). FUBINACA and a-PVP are two of the most dangerous synthetic cannabinoids which have been reported to cause numerous deaths in the United States. While instruments such as GC-MS, LC-MS have been traditionally recognized as analytical tools for the detection of these synthetic drugs, SERS has been recently gaining ground in the analysis of these synthetic drugs due to its sensitivity in trace analysis and its effectiveness as a rapid method of detection. This present study shows the limit of detection of a concentration as low picomolar for AMB-FUBINACA while for a-PVP, the limit of detection is in nanomolar concentration using SERS.

Validation for use of SERS in Courtroom

In order for a new analytical technique such as surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) to be used in a routine manner, data and studies on the validation of the method are required. In that context, we performed a systematic study of the variability observed at different levels of the analytical procedure (i.e. respectively measurement, sampling, colloids aliquots, colloids batches, laboratories). Our goal is to provide data towards a qualitative validation of the technique for identification purposes. Three molecules of forensic interest were used as probes, respectively crystal violet, methamphetamine and 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT).

Detection and Quantitation of Trace Fentanyl in Heroin by Surface Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy,

In the face of the current opioid epidemic, the detection of fentanyl, a main culprit in overdose deaths, has become critical. Although Raman spectroscopy is a valuable analytic tool for the detection of illicit drugs, it can produce questionable results when applied to trace quantities. On the other hand, surface‐enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) produces large signal enhancements by proximity to metal nanoparticles. We have examined the use of a paper-based substrate impregnated with silver nanoparticles for the detection of trace quantities of fentanyl? alone or as an adulterant in heroin. Quantitative analysis of fentanyl in various mixtures was carried out using a Langmuir isotherm calibration model that relies on intensity-ratios of diagnostic peaks associated with each substance, and an excellent fit (R2=0.964) was obtained.  Linearity was observed at concentrations < 6%, a significant finding as it reflects the nature of street-seized drugs. That linearity was exploited for predictive evaluation of ?unknown? mixtures, and reasonable outcomes were attained. In addition, fentanyl was successfully detected through in-situ? swabbing; however, assessment using a Langmuir model proved difficult. Overall, this work demonstrates a potentially simple and sensitive technique for the forensic detection and quantitation of fentanyl in trace amounts.
